metadata.notes: Complete visual meteor shower list. 110+ established showers exist, but only ~14 produce worthwhile visual rates from Central Europe. Dates are fixed; moon interference must be calculated annually.

showers.name: Quadrantids

radiant.notes: Near the defunct constellation Quadrans Muralis

moon_interference_2026.notes: Moon sets around 4am, best viewing in pre-dawn hours

best_viewing.direction: Radiant rises late; meteors visible all over sky after midnight
best_viewing.notes: Peak is very sharp - timing is crucial. Best rates only last a few hours.

showers.description: One of the best annual showers but often overlooked due to cold January weather and its sharp, easy-to-miss peak. When caught at maximum, rates can rival the Perseids. The meteors are often bright blue, with some fireballs.
showers.photography_tips: Fast peak means you need to be ready on the right night. Use wide-angle lens pointed away from Moon if present.

showers.name: Lyrids

best_viewing.direction: Lyra rises in late evening; best rates after midnight
best_viewing.notes: One of the oldest known meteor showers - observed for 2,700 years

showers.description: An ancient shower observed since 687 BC. Usually produces about 18 meteors per hour but has occasional outbursts. Lyrids are known for bright meteors and occasional fireballs.
showers.photography_tips: Point camera toward Vega region after midnight. Spring nights can still be cold - dress warmly.

showers.name: Eta Aquariids
showers.zhr_notes: Rates vary; better from Southern Hemisphere

radiant.notes: Low on horizon from northern latitudes

best_viewing.direction: Look east toward Aquarius in the hour before dawn
best_viewing.notes: Radiant is low from Europe - many meteors lost below horizon

showers.description: Debris from Halley's Comet produces fast meteors in early May. From European latitudes, the radiant is low, so expect 10-30 meteors per hour rather than the full ZHR. Many meteors appear as 'earthgrazers' skimming the atmosphere.
showers.photography_tips: Low radiant means long meteor trails. Point camera east at low altitude.

showers.name: Southern Delta Aquariids

best_viewing.notes: Often overlooked but provides steady summer meteors

showers.description: A reliable summer shower that peaks just before the Perseids. From southern Europe, rates are better than from northern locations. Meteors are medium-speed and often faint.
showers.photography_tips: Can photograph alongside early Perseids for a two-radiant composite.

showers.name: Perseids
showers.zhr_notes: Consistently high rates; occasional outbursts to 150+

radiant.notes: Circumpolar from most of Europe - visible all night

moon_interference_2026.notes: Excellent conditions - thin moon rises late

best_viewing.direction: Radiant is circumpolar from Europe - meteors visible in all directions
best_viewing.notes: Warm summer nights make this the most popular shower

showers.description: The most popular meteor shower thanks to warm August nights, reliable rates, and a high percentage of bright meteors. The parent comet has a 133-year orbit and last visited in 1992. Perseids are known for bright, fast meteors with persistent trains.
showers.photography_tips: Point camera anywhere in the sky - meteors will appear in all directions. Warm nights allow longer imaging sessions.

showers.name: Orionids

best_viewing.direction: Orion rises late evening - best rates in pre-dawn hours
best_viewing.notes: Second shower from Halley's Comet (with Eta Aquariids)

showers.description: The autumn counterpart to the Eta Aquariids - both come from Halley's Comet. Orionids are very fast meteors with many bright examples and persistent trains. The broad peak allows good viewing over several nights.
showers.photography_tips: Fast meteors mean bright trails. Point toward Orion after midnight.

showers.name: Leonids
showers.zhr_notes: Usually low; famous for rare storm years (1833, 1966, 2001)

best_viewing.direction: Leo rises around midnight in mid-November
best_viewing.notes: Next potential storm: late 2030s when Earth passes near comet orbit

showers.description: Usually modest, the Leonids are famous for occasional spectacular meteor storms - the 1833 storm (100,000+ per hour) helped establish meteors as astronomical phenomena. The next potential storm isn't expected until the late 2030s. Even in normal years, Leonids are among the fastest meteors visible.
showers.photography_tips: Very fast meteors create short, bright trails. May need shorter exposures.

showers.name: Geminids
showers.zhr_notes: Highest rates of any annual shower; increasing slightly each year

moon_interference_2026.notes: Moon rises ~11pm; best viewing in evening before moonrise (8pm-11pm)

moon_interference_2027.notes: Excellent conditions - thin moon sets early

best_viewing.direction: Look anywhere in the sky; meteors radiate from near Castor
best_viewing.notes: Unlike most showers, good rates begin in early evening

showers.description: The king of meteor showers. The Geminids produce the highest reliable rates of any annual shower and are active for several nights around peak. Meteors are medium-speed, bright, and often colorful (yellow/white/green/blue). Uniquely, the parent body is an asteroid, not a comet. Cold December nights are the only drawback.
showers.photography_tips: Slow meteors allow longer exposures. Evening activity means you don't have to stay up late. Dress very warmly!

showers.name: Ursids

moon_interference_2027.notes: Poor conditions - bright moon all night

best_viewing.direction: Look toward Ursa Minor (Little Dipper) / Polaris region
best_viewing.notes: Often overshadowed by Geminids a week earlier; coincides with winter solstice

showers.description: A minor but reliable shower occurring near the winter solstice. The circumpolar radiant means meteors can be seen all night from European latitudes. Rates are usually low, but occasional outbursts have produced 50+ per hour. A nice bonus after the main Geminid show.
showers.photography_tips: Circumpolar radiant means you can photograph all night. Low rates mean patience is required.

showers.name: Alpha Capricornids
showers.zhr_notes: Low rates but many bright fireballs!

radiant.notes: Active same time as Southern Delta Aquariids

best_viewing.notes: Worth watching despite low rates due to spectacular fireballs

showers.description: A minor shower by numbers, but famous for producing spectacular bright fireballs. The slow-moving meteors often leave persistent trains. Active at the same time as the Southern Delta Aquariids, so a good night for meteor watching overall.
showers.photography_tips: Slow meteors and frequent fireballs make this an excellent photography target despite low rates.

showers.name: Aurigids

best_viewing.direction: Auriga rises after midnight; best rates pre-dawn
best_viewing.notes: Short peak; outbursts possible but unpredictable

showers.description: A minor shower that occasionally produces surprising outbursts. The 2007 outburst reached ZHR of 130. Fast meteors from a radiant near the bright star Capella. Worth monitoring in early September.
showers.photography_tips: Fast meteors create bright short trails. Be prepared for potential outburst activity.

showers.name: Draconids
showers.zhr_notes: Usually very weak; historic storms in 1933, 1946 (thousands/hour)

radiant.notes: Near the head of Draco; circumpolar from Europe

best_viewing.direction: Look toward Draco in the northwest after sunset
best_viewing.notes: Best in evening unlike most showers; radiant sets after midnight

showers.description: Usually a very weak shower, but historically produced spectacular meteor storms when Earth passed close to fresh comet debris. The 1933 and 1946 storms produced thousands of meteors per hour. Exceptionally slow-moving meteors. Always worth checking in case of unexpected outburst.
showers.photography_tips: Very slow meteors. Evening activity (unusual). Monitor IMO alerts for potential outbursts.

showers.name: Southern Taurids
showers.zhr_notes: Low rates spread over long period; many fireballs

radiant.notes: Part of the Taurid Complex associated with Comet Encke

best_viewing.direction: Taurus rises in late evening; best after midnight
best_viewing.notes: Extended activity period; look for fireballs throughout October-November

showers.description: Part of the Taurid Complex, a broad stream of debris from Comet Encke. While rates are low, the Southern Taurids are famous for producing bright fireballs and bolides. The extended activity period means Taurid fireballs can appear throughout October and November.
showers.photography_tips: Long activity period allows many photography opportunities. Watch for bright fireballs.

showers.name: Northern Taurids
showers.zhr_notes: Low rates; many fireballs; 7-year enhancement cycle

radiant.notes: Slightly north of Southern Taurids radiant

best_viewing.direction: Taurus is well-placed all night in November
best_viewing.notes: Combined with Southern Taurids, October-November has consistent fireball activity

showers.description: The northern branch of the Taurid Complex. Like the Southern Taurids, rates are low but fireballs are common. Some years show enhanced activity ('Taurid swarm years') with increased fireball rates. The slow-moving meteors are easy to spot and photograph.
showers.photography_tips: Slow meteors ideal for photography. November nights offer long darkness hours.
